channel.title: Blogs on California Home Rates
channel.description: Recent content in Blogs on California Home Rates

item.title: California Mortgage Rates by Loan Type: Conforming, FHA, VA, Jumbo (2026 Guide)
item.description:
Why California Mortgage Rates Vary by Loan Type

California borrowers face six distinct mortgage rate tiers based on loan type, loan amount, and government guarantee structure:

  1. USDA (0% down, rural areas) — Lowest rates (6.00%–6.375% as of January 2026)
  2. VA (0% down, veterans) — Second-lowest rates (6.125%–6.50%)
  3. FHA (3.5% down, government-insured) — Slightly below conventional (6.25%–6.625%)
  4. Conventional conforming (up to $806,500) — Baseline market rates (6.375%–6.75%)
  5. High-balance conforming ($806,500–$1,149,825 in California) — 0.125%–0.25% above standard conforming (6.50%–7.00%)
  6. Jumbo ($1,149,825+ in California) — 0.50%–0.75% above conforming (6.75%–7.50%)

Why rates differ: Government-backed loans (FHA, VA, USDA) have lower default risk for lenders (government insures/guarantees the loan) → lenders accept lower interest rates. Jumbo loans have higher default risk (no government backing, larger loan amounts, wealthier but more volatile borrower pool) → lenders charge premium rates.

item.title: How to Lock California Mortgage Rates: 30-Day vs 45-Day vs 60-Day Lock Strategy
item.description:
What Is a Mortgage Rate Lock?

A rate lock is a lender’s written commitment to honor a specific interest rate for a set period (typically 30, 45, or 60 days) while your loan processes through underwriting, appraisal, and closing.

Without a rate lock: Your rate floats (changes daily based on market conditions). If bond yields rise 0.50% during your 35-day escrow, your rate rises 0.50% = $350–500/month more on California loans.

item.title: Regional California Mortgage Rates: Bay Area vs LA vs San Diego vs Inland Empire (2026)
item.description:
Why California Mortgage Rates Vary by Region

California is not a single mortgage market—it’s six distinct regional markets with different lender competition, property values, and rate pricing:

  1. Bay Area (SF, San Jose, Oakland) — Lowest rates (6.375%–6.625% conforming, 6.875%–7.125% jumbo)
  2. Los Angeles & Orange County — Very competitive (6.375%–6.75% conforming, 6.875%–7.25% jumbo)
  3. San Diego — Competitive (6.50%–6.875% conforming, 7.00%–7.375% jumbo)
  4. Sacramento & Central Valley — Moderate pricing (6.50%–6.875% conforming, 7.125%–7.50% jumbo)
  5. Inland Empire (Riverside, San Bernardino) — Higher rates (6.625%–7.00% conforming, 7.25%–7.625% jumbo)
  6. Wine Country & North Coast (Napa, Sonoma, Mendocino) — Highest rates (6.625%–7.00% conforming, 7.25%–7.75% jumbo)

Rate spread across California: 0.25%–0.375% (Bay Area to Inland Empire for same borrower, same loan). On $900K loan, 0.25% = $156/month, $9,360 over 5 years. On $1.5M jumbo, 0.375% = $391/month, $23,460 over 5 years.
